image.altText: Erica Vlasic in her living room.

items.synopsis: Erika Vlasic received two reports about a home she wanted to buy. She said one came back with "no big issues", the other found the property was suited to "demolition".

title.children: When Erika offered $700k for a home, she didn't know it was 'better suited to demolition'

image.altText: An illustration of two women, one with her hand on the other's shoulder, in front of a stained glass window.

items.synopsis: While Jenny was trying hard to be a good Christian, she was hiding a secret shame — one that can be traced back to biblical times.

title.children: Jenny saw fat-shaming in teen magazines. She never expected it would also come from her church

image.altText: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg speaks during a media conference.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy launches a bombastic Tweet from the sidelines of the NATO summit in Lithuania.

title.children: Key takeaways from day one of the NATO summit

image.altText: Man wearing navy uniform

items.synopsis: The Russian military official was shot dead by an unknown assassin while on his morning run after appearing on a Ukrainian blacklist website.

title.children: 'Liquidated': Russian commander on Ukraine's blacklist shot dead on run

image.altText: A placid blue lake surrounded by green forest

items.synopsis: A small lake near the Canada-US border has been chosen as the site that may define the start of a new geological epoch called the Anthropocene.

title.children: A 'golden spike' in Canada could mark the beginning of the Anthropocene Epoch

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous man looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Ned Hargraves says many in his remote desert community still do not understand what they will be voting for, and is calling for the Voice referendum to be postponed so people have to chance to understand it.

title.children: Warlpiri elder will be voting against the Voice in the upcoming referendum. Here's why

image.altText: A young white woman with glasses sits at a desk in front of a laptop.

items.synopsis: Australians targeted by the illegal robodebt income averaging scheme are considering their legal options after the damning royal commission report suggested there was evidence to support a further civil case.

title.children: Robodebt report provides avenue for further civil action and compensation for victims

image.altText: Jarrad Madgwick with mum

items.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of Australians fell victim to the former government's illegal Robodebt scheme. For some, the end of the royal commission brings closure.

title.children: What Robodebt victims and their families think about the royal commission's final report

image.altText: Elina Svitolina crouches down and covers her mouth on Wimbledon's Centre Court

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina tells the world she will celebrate one of the biggest wins of her career with a beer as she returns to the semis of Wimbledon eight months after giving birth.

title.children: Tennis's comeback queen stuns world number one Iga Swiatek to be one match from Wimbledon final

image.altText: ce patterns settle on a car roof in Donnybrook, Western Australia

items.synopsis: If you live in a frost-prone region you are likely familiar with the mosaic-like branches and spirals that stretch across windows and cars on an ice-cold morning. But how does Mother Nature create the magnificent display?

title.children: This isn't art. It's ice, sculpted by Mother Nature

image.altText: A long-distance image shows a security guard with yellow hi-vis vest walking in front of the door to a large, modern building.

items.synopsis: A second young person claims to have received abusive messages from the BBC presenter accused of paying a teenager for sexually explicit images, while BBC insists on keeping him anonymous.

title.children: BBC presenter sent threatening messages to second young person

image.altText: Croc hunting

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister has reignited the crocodile culling debate following an attack at a popular swimming spot. A professor calls her reaction "knee-jerk".

title.children: Should crocodiles be culled again in the NT? Here's what happened last time

image.altText: Margot Robbie in Barbie

items.synopsis: When Hollywood actor and producer Margot Robbie began toying with the idea of a Barbie movie, it was the doll’s polarising success that attracted her to it.

title.children: 'Some people have a lot of problems with Barbie': Margot Robbie on how Barbie became a feminist film

image.altText: A woman walks pass shopping mall

items.synopsis: As China’s economy struggles to recover from the pandemic, consumer confidence in the country is weak and people are turning to social media to share tips on how to consume less and save money.

title.children: Why the hashtag 'consumption downgrade' is trending on Chinese social media

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Wall Street rose boosted by energy stocks on higher oil prices, and RBA governor Philip Lowe will give a major speech on the restructure of the Reserve Bank. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US stocks gain ahead of inflation report, RBA governor set to speak

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets blog, I'm Sue Lannin. Global shares rose overnight as investors await US consumer inflation data, which could see the US Federal Reserve pull back on its interest rate hikes. US inflation is forecast to have increased by 3.1 per cent in June, which would the lowest reading since March 2021, following a 4 per cent increase in May. The Dow Jones index rose nearly 1 per cent, while the S & P 500 and the Nasdaq also gained. Company profit reporting season in the US begins on Friday with big banks including JP Morgan set to report. Coming up today the focus will be a speech by Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe as the Federal Treasurer prepares to announce the next RBA boss. The RBA governor will discuss the overhaul of the central bank and monetary policy. And ANZ and National Australia Bank face a grilling by the House of Representatives economics committee. Join us for all today's business news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks rise ahead of consumer inflation numbers

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets blog, I'm Sue Lannin.
Global shares rose overnight as investors await US consumer inflation data, which could see the US Federal Reserve pull back on its interest rate hikes.
US inflation is forecast to have increased by 3.1 per cent in June, which would the lowest reading since March 2021,
following a 4 per cent increase in May.
The Dow Jones index rose nearly 1 per cent, while the S
P 500 and the Nasdaq also gained.
Company profit reporting season in the US begins on Friday with big banks including JP Morgan set to report.
Coming up today the focus will be a speech by Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe as the Federal Treasurer prepares to announce the next RBA boss.
The RBA governor will discuss the overhaul of the central bank and monetary policy.
And ANZ and National Australia Bank face a grilling by the House of Representatives economics committee.
Join us for all today's business news.

image.altText: Aretha Franklin sings into a microphone

items.synopsis: The decision marks a critical turn in a dispute that has seen her sons locked in a legal battle over the will since her death in 2018.

title.children: Document found in Aretha Franklin's couch is a valid will, jury says

image.altText: Man stands with phone in front of erupting Iceland volcano

items.synopsis: Aerial footage shows streams of orange molten lava and clouds of gas spewing from a snaking fissure outside the capital Reykjavik.

title.children: Icelandic volcano erupts, spewing lava and gas from 900m fissure

image.altText: Professor Leonie Barner

items.synopsis: Scientists have developed an adhesive putty that can glue broken pieces of coral back together, which "has no harmful effects on the marine environment".

title.children: These scientists have a novel way of solving the Great Barrier Reef's coral rubble problem: glue

image.altText: Donna crouches down, smiling, with one hand on Ava the dog, who is sitting attentively on the red carpet.

items.synopsis: For two decades, Donna has travelled confidently around the world and through Sydney with the support of various guide dogs. So what happens when one suddenly passes away?

title.children: More than just a pet, guide dogs give their owners 'absolute freedom'

image.altText: Caity - credit Adam Kennedy ABC News

items.synopsis: The Women's World Cup is less than two weeks away, but in another part of the world a team of Australians are playing in an international soccer tournament of a different kind.

title.children: 'It's been fundamental to my recovery': Homeless World Cup gives hope to people experiencing disadvantage

image.altText: A picture of the tiktok logo, which looks like a musical note, with a silhouette of a person holding a phone.

items.synopsis: A Senate committee slams TikTok for not answering simple questions as the company gives limited evidence about Chinese employees accessing Australian users' data.

title.children: TikTok executive tells parliamentary inquiry they don't know location of own headquarters

image.altText: two men shake hands with red china and blue green solomon islands flags in the background

items.synopsis: The Australian government calls on Solomon Islands and China to reveal the details of a new policing cooperation plan between the two countries, saying it is concerned the deal will invite "regional contest" in the Pacific.

title.children: 'Deep concerns' over Solomon Islands security sector after China signs policing pact

image.altText: A keep out sign on a fence

items.synopsis: As repairs slowly begin, residents still don't know when they will be able to return to their flood-ravaged homes.

title.children: Six months on from WA's worst floods, the scars are still raw in Fitzroy Crossing

image.altText: Daniel Ricciardo at Formula 1 Aramco British Grand Prix

items.synopsis: Daniel Ricciardo will be back and racing for the remainder of the 2023 Formula One season.

title.children: Red Bull 'excited to see' what Ricciardo brings for AlphaTauri as Australian's F1 race return is announced

image.altText: Thumbnail Simon Crisp Marrawah murder.

items.synopsis: Simon Crisp was putting the rubbish out after his partner's shift at a remote country pub in north-west Tasmania when he was shot three times. Ten years on, Tasmania Police are renewing efforts to find his killer.

title.children: Someone shot Simon Crisp as he took out the rubbish. Police think his community knows who

image.altText: Man holding a protest sign saying two-kilometres is too close

items.synopsis: A mining company is given the green light to explore for more minerals in the Central West of NSW, just months after its plan for a mine in the area was approved despite lead contamination fears.

title.children: Community outraged as lead, zinc, and silver miner's exploration plans approved

image.altText: An elevated view of a construction site at night. It is lit up with spotlights. Debris is strewn around and workers can be seen.

items.synopsis: Rescue crews say no-one else is trapped under the rubble, which is expected to take several more days to clear.

title.children: At least two killed, several injured as elevated road collapses in Bangkok

image.altText: a drone shot of a town nestled between red rock ranges

items.synopsis: Police in Kununurra faced significant public unrest over the weekend, with rocks thrown at officers during the incident.

title.children: Kimberley police pushed to limit by 12-hour brawl involving more than 80 people

image.altText: Two rowers with their hands on their hips.

items.synopsis: Australian rowing is developing a new headline act for the Paris Paralympic Games, with the mixed double scull crew of Nikki Ayers and Jed Altschwager on course for a gold medal tilt.

title.children: Rowing duo on course for Paralympic gold having overcome amputation and operations
